feed.title: Combined summary - Anyone can boost - a more efficient alternative to anchor outputs

entry.title: Combined summary - Anyone can boost - a more efficient alternative to anchor outputs
entry.summary:
The recent discourse on the Bitcoin Development Mailing List revisited the concept of Transaction Sponsorship, originally proposed by Jeremy Rubin. This idea introduces a replace-by-fee-rate mechanism with a minimum fee-rate ratio to counteract transaction pinning attacks, particularly Rule 3 pinning associated with ANYONECANSPEND transactions for confirmed outputs. Despite concerns over potential denial-of-service (DoS) attacks, evidence from Libre Relay nodes operating on the mainnet suggests that this mechanism does not significantly increase vulnerability beyond existing free-relay attack susceptibilities. The implementation of such a mechanism, possibly through a soft fork, hints at unlocking novel smart contracting capabilities, extending beyond mere boosting or sponsorship functionalities. An example provided is Ark's application of this mechanism to enhance their connector output scheme, demonstrating both the utility and the complexities involved in coordinating multiple parties within these transactions.
Peter Todd raises critical concerns regarding the security and reliability of outsourced transaction sponsorship services. He questions what prevents these services from engaging in dishonest practices, such as replacing a user's transaction after payment or selling the same sponsor transaction space to multiple users, leading to conflicting transactions. Todd contemplates employing a straightforward pay-for-signature scheme facilitated by signature adaptors and a Lightning Network supporting PTLCs; however, he acknowledges similar trust issues. The challenge lies in reducing reliance on trust without compromising the efficiency of sponsor transactions. Furthering the discussion, Todd shares insights on efficient sponsor transactions through a [forum thread](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/improving-transaction-sponsor-blockspace-efficiency/696), emphasizing the ongoing quest for more secure and efficient transaction sponsorship methods.
Fabian's communication with Martin highlights an ongoing debate within the community concerning the evolution of transaction sponsorship concepts. While noting similarities between Martin's proposal and Rubin's 2020 concept, Fabian points out potential structural differences, notably in how sponsored transactions are referenced. He stresses the importance of clearly distinguishing Martin's idea from previous discussions to foster a deeper understanding and potentially uncover a more compelling solution. This conversation underscores the dynamic nature of the discourse surrounding transaction sponsorship, encouraging contributions that build upon previous knowledge to push the boundaries of what's possible within the domain.
Peter Todd's proposal introduces an innovative approach aimed at enhancing Bitcoin protocol efficiency by addressing the limitations of anchor outputs and Child Pays for Parent (CPFP) methods in managing presigned transactions. His "anyone can boost" model proposes a streamlined process allowing any transaction to be boosted by including its Transaction ID in the annex of a new boosting transaction, valid only if both transactions are confirmed in the same block. This method aims to mitigate network spam and DoS attacks by distributing resource requirements across multiple transactions, thereby deterring attackers due to the prohibitive costs. Moreover, it presents an opportunity for more efficient fee-boosting services by enabling simultaneous boosts of multiple transactions, potentially lowering costs and improving the user experience. However, the implementation of this proposal requires a soft fork, presenting technical and community challenges that necessitate careful consideration and dialogue within the Bitcoin ecosystem.
